slidelink.displaytext: Discovering and Collecting Data (Total Session Length: 12:19)
Skills to Use Data For Good
Skills to Use Data for Good (1:22)

search.slidetext: discovering & collecting data: practical advice for government managers carter hewgley funded by a grant from the www.thegovlab.org

director of analytics & performance at the center for government excellence (govex), johns hopkins university experience in: local government (fairfax county dept of management & budget, dc public schools) “state” government (dc office of the city administrator) federal government (federal emergency management agency) harnessing the power of data can transform public service (and public servants) for the better carter hewgley
session outline discovering & collecting data discovering & collecting data validating data the skills to use data for good

discovering and collecting data seven practical tips 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 create demand for interdisciplinary projects start a conversation conduct a data inventory through data governance leverage open data use foia (as a last resort) crowdsource the unknown survey your residents

discovering and collecting data internally 1 start a conversation create opportunities for horizontal conversations (with people across your programs and departments) listen for examples of people flying blind (e.g., does your water department have information that the public health department could use to better target outreach on lead poisoning prevention?)

discovering and collecting data internally 2 create demand for interdisciplinary projects convene multiple stakeholders around key challenges make it their job to collaborate and find insights (it is a lot more likely that the data will be shared if there is a specific project which requires commitment to deliverables and deadlines)

discovering and collecting data internally 3 conduct a data inventory through data governance start treating data like an enterprise asset to be governed (i.e., establish a governance process for how data should be handled) inventory your systems and the data inside them (e.g., what data your government has and does not have)

discovering and collecting data externally 4 leverage open data data has never been more open, so take advantage of it your city, state, & federal government all have data you need have you identified a gap in your government’s internal knowledge?

discovering and collecting data externally 5 use the freedom of information act (as a last resort) use foia (as a last resort) this amazing right should be a last resort be specific about the purpose, source, and format * if you aren’t in the united states, check if your country gives you the legal right to request information from your government — and take advantage of that right!

discovering and collecting data externally 6 crowdsource the unknown identify an information gap relevant to a key challenge make sure people have a real opportunity to close that gap when data does not exist, it’s time to collect it. crowdsourcing: the idea that if we each contribute our individual knowledge of a subject, the collective knowledge we create will be a much more accurate reflection of the truth. e.g., yelp crowdsources the quality of restaurants.
discovering and collecting data externally 7 survey your residents think about purpose and user experience (keep it short, simple, fun, and clear) factor in scalability and inter-rater reliability

quick survey primer scalable surveys produce results which fall across a wider range of possible scores, increasing your ability to distinguish variation and measure changes over time. surveys with inter-rater reliability contain questions and response options understood to mean the same thing from one respondent to another. low scalability i don’t know (0) no (1) yes (2) low inter-rater reliability do you consider your community to be a safe place? city neighborhood medium scalability no basis to determine (0) strongly disagree (1) disagree (2) neutral (3) agree (4) strongly agree (5) high inter-rater reliability thinking about the neighborhood surrounding your place of residence, do you agree or disagree that it has a low occurrence of violent crime (e.g. murder, assault, armed robbery)?

validating your data three key elements 1 make sure the data comes from the most authoritative source 2 make sure the data makes sense based on what you know about the problem 3 try and triangulate the data to verify its accuracy (use other data to cross-check the data you have)

skills to use data for good intellectual curiosity problem-solving orientation comprehensive excel functionality (this includes sorting, pivoting, building charts, using the analytics packages, writing formulas, and using macros) programming skills

in summary discovering and collecting data begins by: start a conversation with your whole team start treating data like an enterprise asset use open data as a first resort leverage the wisdom of the crowd and the opinions of your residents validate your data before making important decisions hire curious people with 21st century computer skills and a penchant for problem solving
